text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with crab-stuffed corn muffins
that's right i've gotten a lot of food
wishes for easy yet exciting and
different football food so the next time
you're gonna have people over for the
big game maybe serve these and i know
you're thinking do the smelly drunken
slobs i call friends deserve something
that's nice
probably not but let me show you how to
make these anyway just in case so we're
gonna start with our crab filling so i
have 8 ounces of beautifully sweet fresh
Dungeness crab meat to that we're gonna
add a little bit of mayonnaise a little
bit of sambal or any other kind of
crushed red chilies of course you could
use freshly chopped I'm also gonna put
in a few drops of Worcestershire sauce
and then to kind of bind everything
together some shredded pepper jack
cheese and if you don't like the spicy
you can just use regular Monterey Jack
or some cheddar but I'm gonna grate a
couple ounces of that in and then last
but not least about a teaspoon of
freshly grated lemon zest and that's
pretty much our crab filling so I'm
gonna take a fork and mix that up and of
course I want it well combined but I
don't necessarily want to shred every
single little piece of crab so I'm gonna
be semi gentle and by the way if you're
gonna make this try to get fresh nice
sweet crab meat if you can't frozen will
work just make sure you thought and
squeeze out all the excess water and if
you're having trouble finding nice crab
where you live may I suggest quitting
your job uprooting your family and
moving to San Francisco we have great
crab here ok
and once I think that's mixed I'm gonna
go ahead and wrap it up and refrigerate
until needed alright and if you thought
the crab filling was easy wait until you
see how simple the corn muffin mix is so
in a bowl we're gonna take some regular
all-purpose flour some cornmeal a little
bit of salt a little bit of baking soda
not powder soda and that's it for what
we call the dry ingredients and they're
called that because well you know and
before we add the wet ingredients we're
gonna go ahead and take a whisk and just
mix that up make sure everything is
combined just like that to that we're
gonna add a couple large eggs a little
bit of chopped green onion and that's
optional but I had a couple of green
onions hanging around and I said hey
green onions have a proven track record
of being delicious with crab and corn so
I threw it in I'm also going to add some
buttermilk and some melted butter
alright and all you're gonna do is take
your whisk and just give it a stir
I start in the middle kind of break up
the eggs and then just give it all a mix
together remember our philosophy about
not over mixing things all right we
don't over mix on purpose because that
would be crazy but at the same time we
don't obsess about over mixing so just
mix it until you see almost all the
flour incorporated then switch to a
spatula clean off your whisk by the time
you scrape down the sides of the bowl
and give it one last mixed everything
will be combined and you're ready to
scoop into your muffin tins so we're
gonna set that aside to prep your muffin
tins and I'm just using your standard
twelve muffin tin I believe that's
technically a nonstick pan but
regardless I'm gonna give it a spray
with the canola oil and then we're gonna
evenly distribute our batter between all
twelve cups they should come up about
three-quarters of the way as you see
there and before we add the crab we got
to give it the old tap a tappa a very
firm and enthusiastic tap a table all
right you really want to sell that
batter you want any air bubbles
underneath and at that point you can
take out your crab mixture and put a
nice big pile in the center of each one
you should have just enough to put a
nice big spoon on each and once you
divide that evenly go ahead and take
your finger and just push it down in the
center just like that and you'll see how
that batter sort of comes up around the
outside and that's exactly what you want
okay so push it push it real good and
when all your crab is pushed down go
ahead and top with just a little more
cheese that's optional in fact you know
what never mind
I'm giving you too many optional steps
put some more cheese on top just a
little bit it's gonna make the top look
nice it's gonna kind of protect that
crab stuffing a little bit and that is
ready for a preheated oven that's gonna
go in at 375 for between 25 minutes and
a half-hour until they look like this
beautiful golden corn muffins stuffed
with crab can you believe it I mean I
made these and I can barely believe it
and yes because we sprayed them and we
used a nonstick pan you should come out
very easily sometimes a little bit of
the cheese on the edge sticks but if you
loosen that you'll see they will release
I like to let them cool for about 10
minutes in the pan and
transfer them to a baking rack to cool
down to just warm all right if they're
too hot I don't think you're really
gonna appreciate the crab and cold is
you know cold so I like to eat these
warm and your guests will go nuts you
can see here you pretty much have a
standard corn muffin with a solid center
of crab salad super super delicious this
really reminded me kind of like a
lobster roll or a crab roll where they
just take that fresh seafood with a
little bit of warm butter and put it on
the toasted hot dog bun man I love those
things so this really reminded me of
that only of course it was a corn muffin
these really were delicious and I think
would make a very unusual and very
welcome change of pace to your big-game
snack table so I hope you give these a
try head over to food wishes calm for
all the ingredient amounts and more info
